text: BACKGROUND : <extra_id_0> Tumor necrosis factor alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) is an important mediator of septic shock .

text: Previous studies have implicated activation of both protein kinase C ( PKC ) and protein tyrosine kinases ( PTK ) in LPS - induced NF-kappaB activation and <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production .

text: We hypothesized that inhibition of either PKC or PTK would decrease LPS - induced NF-kappaB DNA binding and <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> release in human monocytes .

MATERIALS AND METHODS : Human monocytes were stimulated with PMA ( 50 ng / ml ) alone or LPS ( 100 ng / ml ) with and without a nonspecific serine / threonine protein kinase inhibitor staurosporine ( Stauro ) , a specific pan-PKC inhibitor bisindolylmaleimide ( Bis ) , or an inhibitor of PTK genistein ( Gen ) .
<extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> release in culture supernatants was measured by an ELISA .
NF-kappaB DNA binding was evaluated by electrophoretic mobility shift assay .
RESULTS : LPS increased NF-kappaB DNA binding and <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> release in human monocytes .

text: CONCLUSIONS : These results suggest that LPS - induced NF-kappaB activation and <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> release in human monocytes are independent of PKC activity .
